summary: Ordering integers is about placing numbers on a number line. Numbers increase as you move right, and decrease as you move left. Bigger numbers are always on the right side of smaller numbers.

concepts.title: Rule 1: Number Line
concepts.kid_friendly: On a number line, numbers get bigger as you move right and smaller as you move left.

concepts.title: Rule 2: Comparing
concepts.kid_friendly: If one number is to the right of another, it is bigger.

concepts.title: Rule 3: Positive vs Negative
concepts.kid_friendly: All positive numbers are greater than any negative number.

worked_examples.title: Example 1: Compare -2 and -7
steps: On a number line, -2 is to the right of -7.

worked_examples.title: Example 2: Order 4, -1, 0
steps: On a number line, -1 is farthest left, then 0, then 4.

teaching_tips: Use a physical number line on the floor for kids to walk right or left.
Emphasize that 'bigger' means farther to the right.
Remind kids that negative numbers closer to zero are larger (e.g., -2 is greater than -5).

easy.explain: -3 is to the right of -8 on the number line.

easy.prompt: Order these numbers from least to greatest: 2, -1, 5

medium.explain: 0 is greatest, then -2, -4, and -7 is smallest.
-15 is farther left on the number line.

challenge.prompt: Order these numbers from least to greatest: -10, 3, -1, 7, -5
challenge.explain: All negatives come first in order: -10 < -5 < -1 < 3 < 7.
-6 is to the right of -12 on the number line.

extreme.explain: Arrange from left to right on the number line.

extreme.prompt: True or False: -20 is greater than -15.
extreme.explain: -20 is farther left, so it is smaller.
Line up from smallest (most left) to biggest (most right).
